Introduction

Spontaneous abortion (SAB), or miscarriage, is defined as the loss of a pregnancy at <20 weeks gestation.  It occurs in 10%-20% of recognized pregnancies, with the majority happening in the first trimester (ie, early pregnancy loss).  SAB exists on a spectrum and is categorized based on presentation, cervical examination, and ultrasonography findings.  The condition is often associated with chromosomal abnormalities, but other factors can also contribute.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



The pathogenesis of SAB, a loss of pregnancy at <20 weeks gestation, is usually multifactorial, and a specific cause is not always identified.  Etiologies include fetal or maternal factors that interfere with normal implantation, embryonic and fetal development, trophoblast growth, and fetal blood supply.

Fetal factors



  • Chromosomal abnormalities (most common cause, accounting for up to 70% of cases) can cause early disruption of embryonic development.  Therefore, they are more likely to be found in SABs at <10 weeks gestation.  Trisomies (especially trisomy 16), monosomy X (Turner syndrome), and triploidies are frequently implicated.
  • Congenital anomalies or fetal structural defects (eg, anencephaly (
    image 1
    ))

Maternal factors



  • Prior SAB:  risk increases for each additional SAB and for SABs that occur at later gestational ages
  • Advanced maternal age (age >35):  due to both an increased risk for fetal chromosomal abnormalities and maternal chronic medical conditions
  • Chronic medical conditions:  diabetes mellitus, hypertension, thyroid disorders, autoimmune disorders (eg, antiphospholipid syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus), and obesity
  • Environmental factors:  smoking, use of cocaine or methamphetamines, and exposure to toxins (eg, radiation, heavy metals)
  • Uterine abnormalities (eg, fibroids, adhesions, uterine lateral fusion defects (
    figure 1
    )):  can interfere with implantation and placental development
  • Infections:  such as syphilis, listeria, and rubella
  • Uterine trauma:  such as amniocentesis

Clinical presentation and diagnosis



SABs exists on a spectrum and are categorized based on clinical presentation, cervical examination, and ultrasonography findings (

figure 2
).

Missed abortion



A missed abortion, also known as an asymptomatic pregnancy loss, is often diagnosed on a routine ultrasonography (

figure 3
).  If symptoms are present, it is generally resolution of early pregnancy symptoms (eg, nausea, fatigue, breast tenderness):



  • Physical examination:  closed cervix
  • Ultrasonography:  absence of fetal cardiac activity or an anembryonic pregnancy (a gestational sac without a yolk sac or embryo) (
    image 2
    )

Inevitable abortion



An inevitable abortion refers to a miscarriage that will occur.  Patients typically present with abdominal cramping and vaginal bleeding/spotting.  Because they are early in the process of miscarriage, ultrasonography may still show fetal cardiac activity:



  • Physical examination:  dilated cervix with variable amounts of vaginal bleeding
  • Ultrasonography:  products of conception (Â± fetal cardiac activity) within the uterus; products of conception often found in the lower uterine segment

Incomplete abortion



In an incomplete abortion, some of the products of conception have been expelled from the uterus and some remain (

figure 4
).  Patients have abdominal pain/cramping, heavy vaginal bleeding, and passage of tissue and blood clots.  Incomplete abortion can be accompanied by hemodynamic instability if there is significant blood loss:



  • Physical examination:  dilated cervix, usually with ongoing vaginal bleeding, and there may be visible tissue at the cervical os (depending on the location of the remaining tissue)
  • Ultrasonography:  products of conception within the uterus and cervix; ultrasonography may still show fetal cardiac activity, but less commonly at this stage

Complete abortion



A complete abortion is diagnosed when all pregnancy tissue has been expelled from the uterus (

figure 5
).  Patients typically experience abdominal pain/cramping (uterine contractions), heavy vaginal bleeding, and passage of products of conception:



  • Physical examination:  closed cervix
  • Ultrasonography:  empty uterus, indicating the passage of all products of conception


Light bleeding is common for several weeks following the miscarriage.

Laboratory evaluation



Patients with SAB typically have the following laboratory evaluation performed:



  • Complete blood count:  to assess for anemia and signs of infection.
  • Serum Î²-hCG level:  there are no hCG findings diagnostic for pregnancy loss, but relative findings from serial measurements may be helpful.  In a normal pregnancy, hCG is expected to double every 48 hours (minimum rise by 50%).  An abnormal rise may suggest a nonviable pregnancy (or a pregnancy located outside the uterine cavity).
  • Blood type and antibody screen:  to determine Rh status because Rh-negative women may require Rho(D) immunoglobulin to prevent isoimmunization, depending on the gestational age of the SAB.

Differential diagnosis



  • Ectopic pregnancy (
    figure 6
    ):  This can present with similar symptoms (eg, pelvic pain and vaginal bleeding in the setting of a positive pregnancy test).  On ultrasonography (
    image 3
    ), ectopic pregnancies appear as a complex adnexal mass with a surrounding ring of vascularity and no visualized intrauterine pregnancy.  A ruptured ectopic pregnancy may be seen as significant free fluid (ie, blood) on ultrasonography, and patients often have significantly more abdominal pain and hemodynamic instability.
  • Pregnancy of unknown location:  An intrauterine pregnancy is determined definitively by the presence of either a yolk sac (seen around 5-6 weeks gestation) or fetal pole (seen around 6 weeks gestation) within the uterine cavity (
    image 4
    ).  If the ultrasonography is performed too soon after the last menstrual period, the uterus may appear empty.  This may occur if the intrauterine pregnancy is too early to detect sonographically, or it may be an early ectopic pregnancy.  Serial sonograms and hCG levels ultimately determine the location of the pregnancy.
  • Threatened abortion (
    figure 7
    ):  This is a term used to refer to bleeding that occurs in early pregnancy in the absence of a clear diagnosis of miscarriage.  Physical examination demonstrates a closed cervix.  Ultrasonography demonstrates an intrauterine pregnancy with fetal cardiac activity.

Management



SAB is a disorder that exists on a spectrum.  Management is based on the hemodynamic status of the patient and the type of SAB.  Any patient with hemodynamic instability requires urgent surgical intervention with a dilation and curettage (D&C) to control the bleeding (

figure 8
).



For patients who are hemodynamically stable without signs of infection, 3 general options for treatment exist:



  • Expectant management involves no intervention, but rather allows time for spontaneous expulsion of products of conception.  This is most often offered to patients with missed abortions in the first trimester.
  • Medical management involves misoprostol (a prostaglandin analog) and mifepristone (a progesterone antagonist) to induce expulsion of products of conception.  This can be used for missed abortions, stable incomplete abortions, or inevitable abortions.
  • Surgical management with either suction D&C or manual vacuum aspiration can be used to evacuate the products of conception from the uterus.  "Dilation and evacuation" refers to the surgical uterine evacuation performed at â‰¥13 weeks gestation.


Patients with completed abortions do not typically require additional management.

Pathology



The products of conception are sent for pathologic examination if a D&C is performed or if the SAB occurs in a healthcare setting (many patients have an SAB at home).  The pathology of SAB depends on the gestational age as well as the underlying cause.



Tissue passed spontaneously or obtained through D&C after an early miscarriage is known collectively as products of conception (which includes placental and fetal tissue).  There may be an empty gestational sac (ie, blighted ovum or anembryonic pregnancy) or a recognizable embryo or fetus (

image 5
).



With more advanced gestations, evaluation of the fetus and placenta may reveal findings specific to the cause of the SAB (eg, fetal congenital anomalies, placental abscesses with Listeria monocytogenes infection).  Histologic examination shows decidual tissue and chorionic villi.

Special consideration: septic abortion



A septic abortion is an intrauterine infection that occurs in relation to a spontaneous or induced abortion that can complicate any stage of pregnancy loss (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
).  Septic abortions typically occur when retained products of conception become infected by ascending vaginal flora (eg, anaerobes, gram-negative bacilli, gram-positive cocci), leading to a polymicrobial infection.



Patients often have fever, chills, heavy vaginal bleeding, abdominopelvic pain, and malodorous and purulent vaginal discharge.  Many patients are hemodynamically unstable (ie, in septic shock):



  • Clinical examination shows uterine or cervical motion tenderness and purulent cervical discharge
  • Ultrasonography varies based on the timing of the pregnancy loss.  Most often, remaining products of conception have become infected and necrotic and appear as intrauterine echogenic material.  There may be spread of infection beyond the uterine cavity, seen as a tuboovarian abscess or hydrosalpinx.


Septic abortion is a medical emergency.  Delay in treatment can lead to the spread of infection from the fetus and placenta to the myometrium, which can lead to sepsis, acute respiratory distress syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death.



Therefore, management is with surgical uterine evacuation (to remove infected tissue) and broad-spectrum parenteral antibiotics.  In addition, blood cultures and sexually transmitted infection testing are collected to help guide management.  Patients who do not improve despite treatment may require hysterectomy, particularly if infection with toxin-producing bacteria (eg, Staphylococcus aureus, group A Streptococcus, Clostridioides species) is suspected.

Prognosis



The prognosis following a single SAB is generally good, and most women go on to have successful subsequent pregnancies.  The prognosis is further improved in women who have previously had a live birth.  However, recurrent pregnancy loss (â‰¥2 SABs) requires further evaluation to identify underlying causes (eg, inherited chromosomal abnormalities, uterine anomalies, maternal complications [antiphospholipid syndrome]).



Recurrent pregnancy loss is discussed in a separate dedicated article.

Prevention



The incidence of SAB is high, and there is no way to prevent all miscarriages.  However, optimizing maternal health by optimizing chronic medical conditions (eg, diabetes, hypertension) and limiting negative environmental factors (eg, smoking and alcohol cessation) can lower the incidence for some individuals.  In addition, work-up and treatment of known causes of miscarriage (eg, uterine septum, submucosal fibroids) in individuals with recurrent pregnancy loss can reduce further losses.

Summary



Spontaneous abortion, or miscarriage, is defined as the loss of a pregnancy at <20 weeks gestation.  Spontaneous abortions are categorized based on presentation, cervical examination, and ultrasonography findings (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  Management includes expectant, medical, and surgical options, which are guided by the patient's hemodynamic stability and preference.
